PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Local Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action nor legislate in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To, the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth government

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
i. a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
ii. subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programmes,
iii. farmer unrest at seed prices,
iv. monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
v. increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Customs Regulations: Importation of Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That Regulations and an Ordinance before the Parliament amend the Customs ( Prohibited Imports) Regulation and the Customs (Cinematograph and Films) Regulations and supersede the A.C.T. Objectionable Publications Ordinance in such a manner as to be harmful to society by removing from existing Commonwealth Law.
1. That the Attorney-General enforce existing laws;
2. The power to prevent the importation and sale of hard core pornography (e.g. x-rated videos) and publications which consistently incite the use of hard drugs ;
3. The power to prevent the importation and sale of grossly obscene publications including those associated with blasphemy;
4. The power to require videos for non-commercial use to be registered by the Films Censorship Board before release from Customs.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should disallow the new Regulations and Ordinance and ensure:
1. That the Censors more appropriately reflect reasonable and responsible community attitudes;
2.That further measures be taken in association with the States to protect Australians, particularly women and children, from exploitation;
3. That, because of the importance of this issue to the whole community a conscience vote be permitted to all Members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decisions which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.

PETITION.TITLE: Wynyard Airport, Tasmania

(a) We are shocked and disappointed at the Federal Government's decision not to upgrade the Wynyard Airport.
(b) This decision will inevitably lead to downgrading and closure of the Wynyard Airport.
(c) Closure of Wynyard Airport will cause grave hardship and inconvenience to the people of the North West and West Coast regions of Tasmania.

And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation. We agree that:
1. PVR will inhibit the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding.
2. PVR will not enhance Australia's access to plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
3. PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
4. PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by foreign interests not responsible to the Australian people.
5. The proprietary rights granted by PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Parliament refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Library: Child Care Facilities
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully believing that:
There is demonstrated evidence of a need for child care facilities by staff, users, and potential users of the National Library of Australia and surrounding buildings in Parkes, A.C.T.;
There are at present no such existing facilities.
Provision has already been made for inclusion of the facilities in planned extensions to the Library.

Humbly petition that your Honourable House reverse the decision by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment disallowing provision for child care facilities in the extensions to the National Library of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for Technical and Further Education Colleges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned teachers and students working and studying in TAFE colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We assert that TAFE, with over 1 million students, requires greatly improved resources if it is to continue to train Australia's skilled workforce effectively.

2. We call upon the Commonwealth Government to provide greatly increased funds to ensure that TAFE is accessible to all Australians, unlike the present time when thousands of people are turned away from TAFE colleges each year.

3. We urge the Commonwealth Government to equip TAFE workshops with the advanced technology used in modern Australian industries, and to expand TAFE's capital works program so that sufficient quality accommodation is available for TAFE teachers and students.
4. We ask that the Commonwealth Government greatly increase TAFE's recurrent expenditure, so that TAFE can respond quickly and flexibly to industry, Government and community demands.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Retirement Income Policy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:
1. the Hawke Labor Government's retirement income policies are piece-meal, inconsistent and make no provision to encourage people to save towards their retirements; and
2. the Government's proposed assets test legislation is iniquitous and, if enacted, its effects would be discriminatory.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, urges the Government to:
1. scrap its proposed assets test legislation;
2. either institute a broad enquiry into Australia's retirement income and taxation systems or await the outcome of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare's work on this matter; and
3. following the report of such a wide enquiry, institute a retirement income policy which is fair and equitable, that encourages self-provision and which will be non-discriminatory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, I present a report dated May 1984 on plant variety rights, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

Later I will seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a tabling statement, but before I do so I will make a few general points. As indicated in the preface to the report, the Plant Variety Rights Bill 1982 was referred to the previous Committee in September 1982. The investigation of that Committee was not completed when the thirty-second Parliament was dissolved. When the new Committee was elected and members were appointed they decided to continue with the topic, not related to the Plant Variety Rights Bill 1982 of course but just the general topic of plant variety rights. The Committee used the material collected to that point as the basis for its investigations.

I should explain that when the new Committee was established only one of the original Committee members remained. Also a new Secretary had been appointed. I think it is a tribute to the present secretariat that so much of the original material was utilised both in the carrying out of the inquiry and in the preparation of the report which I believe makes a significant contribution to the debate in this most important area. Although the tabling statement does so I would like to pay tribute here to former Senator Andrew Thomas who was Chairman of the Committee-in fact he took over from Senator Durack-and was Chairman for quite some time; to former Senator Geoff McLaren, who was on the National Resources Committee all the time he was a senator; and to the former Secretary of the Committee, Derek Abbott, who is still here but is now engaged on other duties.

During the inquiry we had some interesting private discussions on the place of members' personal views in the preparation of a report. We canvassed such topics as should the report be a digest of current opinion on the topic, should the members attempt to subjugate their personal bias in the particular area and also the role of the report itself, whether it should simply be advice to government, whether it should be background material for senators with various options presented, or perhaps even a definitive statement on the topic or a number of others. Discussions with members of other committees suggested that they are also asking the same sorts of questions that we asked. I suggest that the Senate look at this whole area, either by setting up an ad hoc committee to prepare a working paper for discussion in this place or that the committee of chairpersons , deputy chairpersons and secretariat look at the whole area and suggest what is the role of the report and what is the role of committee investigations.

Although I have done so in the tabling statement I would now like in this place to thank members for their contribution and work which they put into the report. I also commend the secretariat for the assistance which it has given so freely during the inquiry and particularly in the preparation of the report. I also thank all of those who made submissions and gave advice and assistance during the currency of the investigation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the tabling statement.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

For the past 20 years there has been debate about whether Australia should adopt a system of plant variety rights such as those operating in Europe, the United Kingdom and the United States. Like copyright and patent rights, these systems provide protection to plant breeders who breed, for example, a new variety of vegetable, grain or rose. Proponents of PVR have argued that this form of protection would provide an increased financial incentive for private investment in plant breeding in Australia, and would make it easier for Australia to import improved patented varieties from overseas. It is claimed that both farmers and consumers would benefit from more disease-resistant, productive and higher quality varieties of food plants and ornamentals.

On the other hand, much genuine concern has been expressed in the community about possible adverse consequences of introducing a system of PVR in Australia. It has been argued that PVR would encourage private investment in plant breeding at the expense of existing government support for public plant breeding, particularly cereal breeding, and that the profit motive could result in the production of not necessarily superior varieties accompanied by heavy advertising campaigns. At another level, it is argued that it is ideologically wrong to facilitate the increased concentration of ownership of the world's food varieties in the private sector.
In this regard PVR in Australia is seen as setting an unfortunate precedent for our Third World neighbours, where the role of private enterprise in food production has been strongly criticised.
The Committee's report is, I believe, as responsive to these concerns as it is to the arguments in favour of PVR.

The Committee considers that a system of PVR would, on balance, be the most appropriate way of improving access to overseas varieties and of stimulating plant breeding in Australia. However, PVR is not by itself an adequate means of addressing these needs. For example, the Committee believes that the possible consequences of PVR on the valuable work currently being conducted in the public sector, particularly in cereal breeding, need to be examined to ensure that adequate funding levels are maintained where appropriate. The Committee has also recommended that publicly bred varieties be eligible for registration under PVR.

The Committee has also been concerned that the advantages of a PVR system should accrue to small plant breeders as well as to larger companies and multinationals. It has therefore made a number of suggestions regarding any proposed legislation which, for example, would prevent foreign plant breeders receiving more favourable treatment than Australian breeders, and would also ensure that any necessary litigation over infringements would not be prohibitively expensive.

The Committee has argued in favour of a merit-testing system for new varities, so that growers can buy varities on the basis of merit rather than on the basis of advertising campaigns. Most of the concerns expressed by consumer groups have , we believe, been answered by these and other recommendations.

The report foreshadows a need to upgrade genetic conservation facilities for germ-plasm of older varieties as these are replaced by new varieties. Concerns about the effect of an Australian PVR system on the Third World should, we believe, be allayed by the discussion on these issues which occupies a central part of the report. The Committee concluded on the basis of the evidence available to it that a decision on the adoption of PVR in Third World countries would be a matter for the governments concerned, and that an Australian PVR system was likely to have very little effect on the activities of multinational corporations in Third World countries. However Australia continues, through the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research and through more direct aid, to provide assistance to Third World countries in food production and research.

The potential inclusion of cereal and other field crop species in a PVR scheme has also been the subject of much debate. In the Committee's view there is sufficient reason for a closer examination of the possible impact of PVR on field crop breeding programs before a decision is made to include these species in a PVR scheme.

The PVR Bill which was put to the Senate in 1982, and which lapsed with the dissolution of the 32nd Parliament, contained a number of provisions which the Committee believes need to be revised. As well as making a number of suggestions for these amendments, the Committee has also recommended that the operation of a PVR scheme be reviewed within five years of its inception.

Paragraphs 1.30 and 1.31 of the report mention the preliminary findings of the study carried out by Dr L. J. Butler and Professor B. W. Marion of the University of Wisconsin-Madison, into the economic impacts of the United States Variety Protection Act (PVPA). This study was undertaken at the request of the United States Senate Agricultural Committee.

The report of that study has now been received and confirms the information provided to the Committee by Dr Butler last year. Butler and Marion conclude in relation to the PVPA: ''Both benefits and costs appear to be modest. There is no evidence that PVPA has triggered massive investments in R & D. Based upon the available evidence, the impact has been very crop specific. However, there is also little evidence of substantial public costs from PVPA. Increases in prices, market concentration and advertising, and declines in information exchange and public plant breeding-the feared costs of PVPA-have either been nil or modest in nature. Thus, at this point in time, the evidence presented in this report indicates the Act has resulted in modest private and public benefits and modest private and public costs''.

The Committee's report is a wide-ranging response to the surprisingly complex array of issues which has surrounded the PVR debate. In recommending to the Government that it consider the introduction of a PVR scheme in Australia, the Committee also asks that any decision to introduce a PVR scheme take account of the other recommendations contained in this report.

Before concluding I should pay tribute to the work of the former members of the National Resources Committee who, in the 32nd Parliament, undertook the bulk of the public hearings into this matter. In particular, I should mention the former Chairman, Andrew Thomas, and the former Deputy Chairman, Geoff McLaren, both of whom are no longer serving in the Senate. PVR was a difficult subject for a committee with five new members to take on and complete at such a late stage, and I wish to commend members for their efforts both during the inquiry and in the consideration of the report.
I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the previous speaker, Senator Robertson, has said, I joined the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources when the thirty-third Parliament was formed. This inquiry has been an interesting examination of a fairly complex matter in which we received a lot of evidence from people whom I regard as very genuine in their attitude. Many of them had absolutely no worries about bringing in a plant variety rights scheme; yet many other people who came before us had some genuine concern. But as the evidence accumulated I, for one, developed a very definite decision that PVR would not be detrimental to this country. In fact, I now believe that we are many years behind some other countries in plant variety rights. Places like New Zealand have had PVR for about 10 years, and they now have access to some varieties of plants that have been denied people within Australia. The summary of the report, at the beginning, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The debate over plant variety rights (PVR) in Australia has produced a substantial amount of written material and a number of seminars and conferences during the past twenty years.

That is a very long time for a discussion to come to fruition. I hope that now that this report has been tabled the Government will act urgently on it, because I believe it is something, as I said, that this country requires. The summary continues:

The Committee's inquiry has provided another possibly wider, forum for those supporting or opposing PVR. In addition to seeking these views, the Committee has also noted the evidence of technical, legal, scientific and economic experts .
The summary goes on:

After considering the potential advantages and disadvantages of PVR and a number of alternatives, the Committee has concluded that PVR is the most appropriate means of improving access to overseas varieties and stimulating plant breeding in Australia.
I will not speak at length, but the first recommendation reads:
The Committee recommends that: (1) the Commonwealth consider the introduction of a PVR scheme in Australia.
The second recommendation states:

(2) all plant species have the potential to be included in an Australian PVR scheme. However, the Committee also recommends that initially any PVR scheme have the potential to include horticultural, ornamental and fodder and pasture varieties only and that before a decision is made to include field crops the Commonwealth suggests to the States that the Australian Agricultural Council examine the possible impact of PVR on field crop breeding in Australia.

There was some discussion at length within the Committee and with people who appeared before us about this matter. I was torn as to whether even at this stage we should recommend that field crops be also included within the PVR system. I think it is something that the Government could very well look at as soon as possible. Another recommendation reads:
(4) if a PVR scheme is introduced its effectiveness and impact be assessed following a minimum of five years operation.

Subsequent to our preparing that report, I received a document which is entitled 'An Economic Evaluation of The Plant Variety Protection Act', dated December 1983. It deals with the American PVR situation. It points fairly clearly to the fact that five years is not really enough time to assess where a PVR scheme is going. On page 105 the report concludes:
Second, in an industry in which new varieties often require 10 years or more to develop, the effects of PVPA--
it says PVPA, which is equivalent to our PVR-
are difficult to detect after only 12 years.

So it is something that will need a lot of examination as time goes on. I am very much in favour of bringing down this scheme. I hope, as I said earlier, that the Government will examine the matter urgently and report to the Senate as to what its action will be or, better still, get on with the legislation that is required. We do make some comments in this report about the previous legislation that was being examined. In closing, I thank all the people who helped us-the staff and all the witnesses who so willingly came before us, some of them on several occasions-to come to our conclusions contained in this report. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory I present two reports on Proposals for Variations of the Plan of Layout of the City of Canberra and its Environs-the 81A series and the eighty-second series, first report. I seek leave to make a short statement relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will refer to some observations contained in the statement and then seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement. The 81A series of variations deals with the quite small variations of some roads in Canberra relating to the area where the project known as the White Industries project is to be built incorporating, firstly, three office blocks and subsequently a hotel and convention centre. This development is certainly welcomed in this community. The variations are quite minor indeed. As a result of this development a considerable amount of parking space in the Civic area will be lost to what is now all day parking for people who work in that area. The Committee stresses the need to move ahead quite quickly with providing alternative parking and permanent parking structures in the area of Civic to enable this problem to be alleviated.

SPEECH.PARA: More recently we have been looking at the eighty-second series of variations in which there were some 19 variations. I will be tabling a report today as a first report to enable at least the Chisholm shopping centre to go ahead. We have not yet completed the balance of the report. The Chisholm shopping centre proposal in the Tuggeranong Valley comprises about 4,000 square metres. The Committee dealt at some length with the evidence that we were given by the National Capital Development Commission only last year in relation to the proposal for the Erindale shopping centre which has now been abandoned in place of a town centre in that area. I will not go into the details of that dispute at present. The Committee was a little disturbed at the way evidence had been given of the need for the Erindale shopping centre a short time ago; and that has now been abandoned in favour of another proposal. We have been somewhat critical of the nature of the planning in that area that has brought this about. There is no doubt that the Chisholm shopping centre is needed and should proceed forthwith. That is why we are dealing with the matter.

We have deferred consideration of one other variation which was put to us which arose in the area of Hawker. There were some objections to this variation. Of particular concern was a letter that had been written by the Chairman of the Committee in his capacity as the member for Fraser (Mr Fry). It contained a statement which at the inquiry the NCDC said was not correct. We felt that that had created a situation between a member and his constituents and their belief as to what should occur, as against what is occurring, that needed some further investigation. This is not a satisfactory situation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the tabling statement prepared by the Committee concerning the two reports.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-

Statement by the Deputy Chairman, Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, Senator Margaret Reid, on tabling the Committee's reports on the 81A series of Variations to the Canberra City Plan and the 82nd series of Variations to the Canberra City Plan

The first Report I have just tabled on the 81A Series of Variations to the City Plan covers only one item and relates to the proposed development of a hotel/ convention centre and office space by White Industries Limited.
The Committee approves the variation, but it is most concerned about the traffic problems and lack of car parking facilities in Civic which will result from this and other future developments.

To overcome the traffic problems, the Committee recommends that the traffic lights proposed by the National Capital Development Commission be established before the first stage of the White Industries Development is completed, and that traffic lights also be provided at the intersection of Akuna and Bunda Streets in the same time scale.

As a result of the significant additional demand for car parking facilities in Civic which will be generated by the White Industries and other proposed developments, the Committee recommends that the National Capital Development Commission and the Department of Territories and Local Government address themselves urgently to accommodating the additional demand by implementing a range of measures.

The Committee also was concerned that it was approving this variation while a number of major aspects of the White Industries Development were still unclear. Accordingly, it has requested that it be briefed on the development when project arrangements have been finalised.
The other Report I have just tabled covers three items from the 82nd Series of Variations to the City Plan and recommends the approval of work valued at $8.15 million.

Variation 15 is concerned with changes to road ways in Chisholm to provide a shopping centre at Chisholm in accordance with a revised strategy for local retail centres in Tuggeranong which include the development of a town centre. The release in May 1984 for a 4,000M2 Group Centre at Erindale and the proposed Group Centre at Chisholm are the first steps in the implementation of this strategy.

The building of a 4000M2 shopping centre at Erindale is a radical change from a previous proposal by NCDC for an 18,000M2 commercial centre centre at Erindale. This was examined by the Committee and reported upon to the Parliament in the 79th Series of Variations in August 1983. The Committee was told then by NCDC that it would be at least ten years before the necessary preconditions existed which would enable the construction of a Town Centre to commence. Because of the severe shortage of retail space in the Tuggeranong area the Committee agreed to the Erindale proposal although it had some misgivings about approving it. The Committee has now been told, six months later, that there have been substantial changes affecting the Erindale Centre proposal and that the Town Centre will now be built.

In the light of the evidence given in the 79th Series, the Committee is surprised and disturbed that it was not formally advised of the major changes to a proposal it had agreed to only recently and on which it had reported its findings to the Parliament. The Committee believes that in order to determine whether Parliament as a whole should be advised of such changes, the Committee should be formally briefed of any major changes to recent proposals reported to Parliament.

The Committee can only reiterate its concern expressed in the 79th Series report about ''the ad hoc nature of planning decisions in Tuggeranong and the delay in the provision of retail facilities''. It can only be hoped that the decisions which have been taken now about the retail structure for Tuggeranong will provide a firm basis for planning and will ensure that retail facilities are established quickly and as required.
The Committee therefore approves the variation to provide access for the Chisholm Group Centre and urges that the site be released for public auction as soon as possible.
Variation 2 proposes an addition to the City Plan of roads to enable an area in Hawker to be developed for housing.

Objectors to the proposal were concerned about the ''T'' junction which would be constructed opposite their properties to provide access to the development. In response to representations made by Mr Ken Fry, MP, to NCDC as the local member on behalf of some objectors to the proposal, it was stated that:
''. . . if the Joint Committee does not support the Commission's proposed access to Murranji Street the sub-division could be modified slightly to delete it.''

When clarification was sought of this statement, NCDC claimed that the statement was incorrect and should not have been included in the letter. They claimed that access to the sub-division as proposed in the variation could not be modified as had been stated in the letter.

The Committee recommends that further consideration of this variation be deferred until NCDC can explain fully why incorrect information was included in its letter and whether in fact the variation can be modified to delete the proposed access from Murranji Street. When this information is provided the Committee will reconsider the matter.
The Committee approves Variation 5 which is concerned with the development of 544 residential blocks at Lyneham.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN BICENTENNIAL ROAD DEVELOPMENT TRUST FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1984ROADS GRANTS AMENDMENT BILL 1984

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 May, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When speaking yesterday to the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill 1984 and the Road Grants Amendment Bill 1984 I said that I was quite opposed to them. The legislation that these Bills seek to amend was one of the most far-sighted and enlightened pieces of legislation to come through this Parliament in the last 10 years. It was, of course, a product of the Fraser Liberal-National Party Government that had the potential to confer great benefits on the Australian nation. The first piece of legislation is being emasculated by the clause which avoids the compulsion for main roads contracts to go to public tender. This Bill shows the inherent dishonesty and financial incompetence of the Government. I refer to the indexing of the levy. The former Government legislated specifically for all the money from the levy to go to roads for a finite period. By being dishonest, indexing the levy and not transferring it to roads, this Government will be ripping off $500m from the motorists by 1988 and, most importantly, $60m from local authorities which are strapped for funds for road works.

SPEECH.PARA: Roads are probably one of the big issues in Australia. Nearly everyone drives a car. Everyone is conscious of the inadequacies of our roads. With the exception of the State of Victoria and parts of New South Wales the road system in the rest of Australia is totally inadequate for our needs. There is an economic penalty from these bad roads. There is also a very human and real penalty involved. Commerce in Australia depends on a very efficient road service. The mining industry and the great rural industries, which together provide the bulk of our export earnings, are very dependent on roads. It is true that the mining industry relies heavily on rail for its bulk transport, but the place of roads for the movement of personnel and equipment is absolutely vital to its success.

Often when we survey roads we overlook the very human effect that a bad road service has in Australia. Particularly in my own State, which is the most decentralised State with respect to population in Australia, there is a very real impost on families as a result of bad roads and that is on top of the very high cost of living in rural areas. Phantom freight and increases in the price of goods which are beyond the real cost of freight put a financial strain on families who live outside the capital cities. Families have the imposition of a bad road system and the costs that come from that.

It is not recognised in this place that the cost of fuel can well be 25 per cent to 30 per cent higher than the already exorbitant prices in the capital city of Queensland. If the price in the city is 41c or 43c a litre it is not uncommon to find that prices in the rural areas are 52c or 53c a litre. Added to that there must be recognition of the fact that when families go anywhere in the country they often have huge distances to travel-distances well in excess of 1, 000 kilometres or a couple of thousand kilometres. So not only are they paying more for their fuel but also they have to use a great deal more fuel to go anywhere for their holidays than do dwellers in the capital city. With bad road systems it means that they are longer on the roads and, most importantly, the costs of repairs to their cars are higher. So the quality of life is very much affected by the inadequate roads we have. Not only the quality of life, the matter of life itself, is a consequence of the roads.

It is very unfortunate in Australia that we have the mythology, promulgated by Federal and State governments, that 100 per cent of the deaths in Australia from road accidents come from the use of alcohol. Alcohol probably is the most potent contributor to death on the road, but it is not the sole contributor. People must not drink and drive or, for the benefit of the Australian Labor Party, smoke marihuana and drive. But it is 100 per cent wrong for anyone to maintain that alcohol is the only cause of deaths on Australian roads. Road safety is very much a matter of road engineering and road conditions. No surveys have been done to establish the percentage, but I would not be surprised if it were as high as 30 or 40 per cent of the causes of road deaths in this country.

Another contributory factor, of course, is driving standards. There is a belief in the country that everyone is entitled to a driver's licence provided he or she goes through the formality of a test. It may well be that not everyone in the community has the necessary inate skills to drive, but that is a lesser issue. The important point is the standard of road engineering in the incidence of death and accidents on our roads.

We need more money for roads and it follows that, since the amount of money we can devote to roads is limited, we must get 100 per cent value from every dollar or every cent we spend on those roads. It is only through private enterprise that we will maximise the value of that dollar spent. It is only by the use of private enterprise contractors in the form of surveyors to survey roads and to design those roads that we can control costs. It is only by using road building contractors from private enterprise and from the use of subcontractors that we will keep down those costs. Private enterprise provides the fastest and the most price competitive way of building roads.

Yesterday I read a quotation from the annual report on the Australian bicentennial road development program and instanced the Queensland experience that in the period during which the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act has been in operation the roads in Queensland have come in at 40 per cent below the main roads estimate. Why, therefore, is the Labor Party denying the proven virtues of the Act and seeking to amend it so that tendering conditions are now compulsory? It is doing it for the basest of political reasons: It is pork barrelling. It is doing it so that the shires and the councils with their day labour can get in on the act which their managerial incompetence denies them in an open tendering situation. In the shires there are road gangs on day labour and building gangs for the roads. There might not be very many people, it depends on the size of the shire. It could be 50, 100 or even 200 people. But if one adds the multiplier effect of their friends and families-it may be a factor of four or six-it becomes quite a passable number of votes. It is important to the Labor Party at shire election times and it is important to the Labor Party in State politics. So the good of the nation is being thrown away to buy a few votes, maybe for the Labor Party to buy a seat somewhere for one of its representatives in local government elections or State elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a pretty low accusation.

—It is a very low act; I am glad Senator Crowley is squirming about it. If local governments wish to get into tendering they have to become competitive. They have a natural advantage over private contractors. Most of the equipment that local governments have is bought under terms which are far more favourable, their financing is much easier, than that for any private contractor , so the huge capital cost of the plant favours them. Of course, they have local knowledge. They have people on site. They do not have to move road teams in and pay accommodation charges. Most importantly, with their local knowledge they have access to building materials, gravel pits and the rest, again made available at rates which are generally below the prevailing commercial level. If local governments and local authorities got their acts together they could compete for those tenders. They would not need the protection of legislation in the insidious form it has here.

SPEECH.PARA: When we were in government we recognised that we had two problems with regard to roads. Firstly, we recognised that we were not getting value for every dollar we spent because the departments of main roads in the various States were doing the tendering. Secondly, we recognised that in most of the States we were being subjected to other forms of pork barrelling. I know that in my own State of Queensland, under the long-serving Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Police, it became a bit of a Bermudan Triangle. When we gave money to the State for a national highway, often we could not find out where that money went. The Federal Liberal and National Party members were unanimous about this Bill when we introduced it into the Parliament. We wanted value for our money. Both Liberal and National Party members were united that this was the way which would benefit the Australian community. Having seen this Bill now successfully in operation for a period in excess of nearly two years, its having had no criticism but only support from the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) and from Senator Gietzelt-I have quotations from Senator Gietzelt supporting the virtues of this Bill without any criticism of its operation-we now have this amending Bill introduced which, quite simply, sets out to deceive the Australian community. It is a shabby way to go about what could have been a very great Australian national achievement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government welcomes the general support of the Opposition of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill 1984 and the Road Grants Amendment Bill 1984 which we are currently debating, even though there are some obvious differences of approach in the contributions of Opposition senators. Of course, when the original Bill, presented by the previous Government, was before the House of Representatives and the Senate the Government indicated that the thrust of the legislation had general support. Of course, we indicated that there were differences between our approach and that of the conservatives generally in respect of the way in which the legislation would ultimately proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, I think it must be said that the Government believes in an efficient public transport system. That, of course, means not only in the rail system but also in the road system. We regard the national highway system to be an integral part of our economy. But it is essential that it is able to perform its vital role in providing services to both the public and private sectors. In fact, the Government is on the public record many times as supporting the need to reduce costs in the service sector. A principal factor in reducing the costs in the service sector is a very efficient and viable transport system, so we are committed to that objective. To achieve that objective we need an efficient and effective road construction program. This, of course, can be carried out only in a co-operative way, between the Commonwealth, the States and, in particular, local government. That, of course, is where we differ from the conservative approach which has been so much a part of the Opposition's contribution to this debate in the Senate.

The roads legislation passed by the Fraser Government-to which I have indicated we gave general support-adopted a very rigid and dogmatic approach which was counter-productive in the way in which the States saw their responsibilities and the way in which local government responded in providing their resources to develop an efficient road system. We believe that the legislation currently before the Senate will result in benefits to the different authorities in the State and local government areas. We believe-the legislation reflects this-that the States can best make the decision as to how road construction will be undertaken.

We do not support the very centralist position of the orginal legislation. It is anathema to the often expressed view of co-operative federalism of the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, and Senator Sir John Carrick. They laid down guidelines and processes in the original legislation that gave the State governments no flexibility whatsoever. It seems to me that the Opposition does not know how to get its act together. People such as Mr Hinze from Queensland sought to have the original legislation changed so that flexibility would be available. Of course, the legislation currently being debated provides for just that flexibility. I find it somewhat difficult to comprehend the rather conservative and Tory expressed view of honourable senators from the State of Queensland. However, I did detect in Senator Bjelke-Petersen's approach, a National Party senator, a somewhat more flexible position than that adopted by Senator MacGibbon, a Liberal Party senator.

What we seek to achieve is to ensure that the States are given the opportunity to make the best available decision. If they want to use their day labour force, which is an important factor in country and rural areas, as surely will be conceded by the Opposition, this legislation will provide for that process. Of course, the onus will be on the States to satisfy the Federal Minister about whatever courses of action they want to take under this flexible approach. We believe that this is a proper exercise of State sovereignty and federal fiscal responsibility. In contrast to the position under the rigid earlier legislation, under this legislation the States may satisfy the Minister of the need to adopt an alternative position.

The Minister has set up suitable guidelines, not in a dictatorial way but in a way that will encourage that flexibility. We do not quarrel with the need of a philosophy of co-operative federalism under which the Commonwealth, the States and local authorities work together. This should apply not only to road construction but also generally to improving the lifestyle of Australians, whether they be in the urban or rural sectors.

The purpose of the legislation is to amend certain provisions and arrangements to give financial assistance to the States and to the Northern Territory. We have to quarrel with the assertions made in the speeches of some Opposition senators. Senator Rae did not go on the rampage about the amounts of funds available for the important aspect of road funding in Australia, but some other honourable senators did. Obviously they have not correctly understood the dramatic increases in road funding allocations made by this Government since it came to office. Honourable senators such as Senator MacGibbon have ignored the fact that in the period from 1975-76 to 1981-82 there was an actual decline in real terms of 23 per cent in Federal funding for road construction in Australia, whereas what is proposed by this Government is an increase for road construction of 45 per cent on the amount provided in the last conservative Budget.

—Prior to the election in 1983, the shadow Minister for Transport, Mr Peter Morris, stated in his part of the election procedures that Labor, after it had won the election, would change the emphasis and would establish in new legislation the flexibility which is characteristic of the legislation we are now debating. Consequently, we are carrying out one of our election commitments, which I think the Government is obliged to do.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the principal factors? In 1982, legislation required the States to maintain in real terms the level of road expenditure and ignored different State needs and processes. As I have indicated, we regarded that as a rigid, inflexible position. As we said in the debate on that matter at the time, we required the Government, although we did not have the support of the Senate, to make the decision that in future legislation sufficient changes would be made to allow the States to make their own decisions, as part of the co-operative effort . We also made the point that in some cases the States were making greater rates of investment in the urban public transport system, and that was necessary in some States. They were therefore required to maintain in real terms their investment in urban public transport in order to qualify for Federal public funding. We found that to be unreasonable because we believed that the States were best able to make that decision based upon their own understanding of their own needs. This legislation is designed to improve that operation.

It varies the requirement for tendering. Under the old legislation tenders had to be called for all construction work on national or arterial road projects. The Government acknowledges that the Opposition, whilst it has a philosophical argument with us on that question, has expressed its support of the legislation. Of course, it is the Government's intention that this will operate from 12 February 1984, which was the date of the decision of the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris). As was raised by Senator Bjelke-Petersen and other honourable senators, the Minister does not intend to use his discretion without a detailed scrutiny of all the factors. So if a State Minister responsible for road construction or highways desires to change the old processes and adopt the new ones inherent in this legislation, he will not make a decision without taking into account all the factors that have been raised by honourable senators.

The legislation also provides that when States fail to spend their funds in real terms in a given year-that can happen for a variety of natural reasons-they will make up the shortfall the next financial year. States that spend more than they have in one year can have that amount regarded as a debit in a subsequent year. So again we will be co-operating with the States when, for their own economic or other reasons, they find that there should be flexibility. In other words, we are going back to the system that operated for many years before the original legislation in 1982.

The legislation also provides that, where a State proposes that part of its urban road allocation be allocated to urban public transport capital works projects, it must maintain in real terms its own capital expenditure on urban public transport. The overall objective of the Government is to help the States to improve and maintain their urban public transport systems and, of course, to improve road construction, particularly of those roads that play a vital part in both our urban and rural economies. Contrary to what has been said by some speakers, we believe this legislation will remove the uncertainties in the construction industry. It will remove the friction that has existed between the Commonwealth and the States in some categories. It will provide stability in employment and rural communities-factors which were debated at length in regard to the previous legislation-and it will provide stability in local government, which is an important road construction authority. As some honourable senators well recognise, in many States the construction authority of the local council is an integral part of the infrastructure of small country towns. Changes in society indicate how important it is to spend as much money as it is humanly possible on the service sector, because today the service sector is required to be efficient and to be extended as it is now an integral part of the way in which our society operates.

I just want to draw the attention of Senator MacGibbon and other honourable senators to the current road funding arrangements. It is possible that the misapprehension that exists flows from inadequate information being available. We have the roads grants program, the Australian bicentennial road development program and what is known as JOLOR-the jobs on local roads program. In this legislation we are providing an estimated $2.5 billion for the ABRD program for the years 1982-83 to 1988-89. We believe that the money made available to the local roads program, $70m, is indicative of the Government's intention to make its financial contribution. Of course, in the roads grants works program $3,650m was provided to the States for the years 1980-81 to 1984-85. The total Commonwealth assistance for roads under all these programs in 1983-84, therefore , is $1.233 billion which represents a 45 per cent increase over the $851m expended in the previous Budget. Suggestions that I am misleading or in some way citing inaccurate figures are not borne out by the amount of funds that have been allocated, which take into account the points raised by Opposition speakers who put cogent arguments for additional Federal funding for roads. The Government has accepted these arguments and has provided an increase of almost 50 per cent from one Budget to the next despite the fact that Budget deficits are difficult for governments, as we are all aware, without wanting to canvass the very difficult financial position the Government found itself in when it came to office in March 1983. More specifically, I should remind Senator MacGibbon that most local government work is undertaken on local roads and that in respect of that work there has never been any tendering requirement under Federal legislation, and none is proposed in the current legislation.

In conclusion I wish to raise one of the points made by Senator Kilgariff who seemed to have some misunderstandings about the amount of funds being made available. Estimated on the basis of his argument, the additional funds paid to the ABRD Trust Fund this year, had payments to the Trust Fund been indexed in line with excise rates, would have been $22m, not the $491m that he suggested. In other words, he is not as good at arithmetic as he is at making statements. There has been no misappropriation of funds. I think it was back in 1929 when the first road tax was placed on motorists for the purpose of road construction, and it has to be said that, in the succeeding 50-odd years, all governments of all political persuasions have not carried out the intention of the original legislation. There is no point in belabouring this Government when all governments, in particular the previous Government of which Senator MacGibbon was a member, carried out exactly the same process of paying that road tax money into Consolidated Revenue and then voting funds annually, or over a five-year period to various road programs.

I stress that the Government accepts the need for an efficient transport system , which includes roads. To that extent it has put its money where its mouth is. It has provided 45 per cent more funds in the three programs concerned. We believe that is as much as the Budget can provide. I think it is a tribute to the Minister for Transport that he was able to convince Cabinet in the very tight economic conditions of the need for that very dramatic increase in road funding. I thank the Opposition for its general support of the legislation, even though I reject some of the main arguments advanced by it in criticism of the Government's Bills.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Moneys to be paid into Road Fund
