It is not an equal footing; it is an unequal footing. In fact, they have numerous advantages which their competitive contractors do not have. The document continues:
Indeed, statutory bodies enjoy advantages (taxation, and absence of need to make profit) that should ensure their competitiveness.
Governmental authorities have a wide cross-section of advantages over their competitors. The document continues:
Statutory bodies must be properly accountable for the outcome of the work they do, both in time and in cost performance.
Tendering provides the only yardstick that ensures there can be meaningful accountability at the end of the job, whether undertaken by the private sector or the public sector.
Under the tendering system the Government will achieve the greatest output per dollar spent.

Quite obviously it is in the public interest-I imagine this is not disputed by any honourable senator in this chamber-that not only the Government but also the people of Australia should achieve the greatest output per dollar spent. The document continues:
The engineering construction industry faces under-employment for at least the next two years and the removal of any degree of opportunity to tender for national roads would increase unemployment.

In the present need for budgetary restraint, the Government should maximise on private sector availability, rather than increase public sector involvement in construction works, which latter can only be at risk of adding to its longer term budgetary commitment.
Tendering allows the Government to draw on all the resources of present excess capacity, equipment, plant and rapid mobilisation.

I wish to point out an important point; that is, the efficient utilisation of available plant. It is extremely unfortunate to see, as I have witnessed in various parts of Australia, some local government authorities in particular purchasing new equipment and plant when other readily available plant not in use could have been hired, or could have been used by the State government for carrying out the total bicentennial roads program. The document continues:

The Government enjoys control under the present arrangements that will be denied by weakening the tendering provisions; it will be very hard for Government to reinstate them if they are once weakened.

Finally, if the Government makes the case for a need for 'Ministerial discretion' in allocating work, such discretion should only be allowed when the Minister knows the cost implications of his decision; this can only occur if there has been prior open competitive tendering.

I find it very hard to understand why the Government should be so sensitive about the final point. As has been pointed out in the second reading debate, there is power for the Minister-for any of the reasons that are set out in the proposed clause 5-if he chooses, to overrule the tendering procedure. But at least he has had the yardstick of seeing what other tenders were made and what other tenders were available. If, because of the criteria which are proposed in clause 5 of the Bill, he wishes to take some other action, it is open to him to do so. I submit on behalf of the Opposition that for the national advantage and for the advantage of the motorists of Australia who have to pay this tax, this is the most efficient and accountable system of providing the expenditure. This would get the earliest and greatest advantages by overcoming any road blocks in getting the work done, getting the tenders called and the work implemented. The tendering system should be used to ensure that the greatest value is obtained for every dollar raised through this excise levy.

The Opposition will oppose clause 5. This would simply remove the proposed amendment which would limit, in the way set out in the clause, the tendering provisions of the original legislation. This would mean that there are a whole set of exempt works which the Minister can give straight to his statutory authority, Department of Main Roads or whatever it may be. The criteria for those exempt works, particularly in paragraphs (e) and (f) read:

(e) are of a kind that are usually carried out by a Department of State of the Commonwealth or of a State or by a particular person by virtue of a law of the Commonwealth or of a State, not being a Department or a person responsible for the construction of roads; or

(f) would need to be carried out by the employees of a State or of a government authority responsible for the construction of roads in order to avoid the occurrence of a loss of employment by, or the inefficient deployment of, a substantial number of those employees, even if the State or authority were to take all practicable steps to avoid that occurrence.

Those criteria for exempting works would mean that any Minister who wished to destroy the tendering system and destroy the prospects of the private sector having any rights of participation in the road construction program could use them to achieve that purpose. They are so wide as to allow an open go to a Minister to make all works exempt. For those reasons, as the existing system has been working well in Tasmania, nine out of the past 11 tenders have gone to the Department of Main Roads in Tasmania. That is because it has been able to undercut. It does not have the overhead costs which its competitors have; it does not have the sales taxes or all the other sorts of excise taxes and various things which its competitors have.

The system has not been as great a benefit to the private sector contractors as it was expected to be. There has been heavy competition. But in summary it means that we have had the best possible amount of work done for the lowest amount of money. The Opposition would wish that situation to continue and for dogma and other things not to come into it which would be possible if the amendment were carried. We will oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government regards clause 5 as an important and integral part of the legislation . I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the amendments we are currently debating are the result of extensive consultations with all the appropriate authorities in the States. Senator Peter Rae is ignoring the fact that the use of clause 5 will come about only as a result of representations from the States to the Commonwealth. We believe that the States should be given an opportunity to present a case. Particular regions within the States should have an opportunity to approach the Minister in the best way possible to get the maximum benefit from the tendering system. After all, this very clause is not envisaged by the Minister as being one that will be extensively used. But we need that flexible approach; we need that opportunity.

SPEECH.PARA: One would have thought that, because of the philosophical approach of members of the Opposition, they would believe in decentralisation. This is an important attempt to recognise that there are circumstances which may not exist in Tasmania but which will exist in Queensland or other States. Whilst we are committed to the principle of tendering as a means of getting the maximum benefit for the taxpayer's dollar we believe that circumstances vary. In some cases the States will come to the Commonwealth and say that it is in their best interests to have this flexible approach. To delete clause 5 from the legislation, which Senator Rae proposes to do, would remove the very flexibility to which the Government is committed as a result of the extensive consultations which have taken place with all the road construction authorities in the States. Naturally we would ask the Senate to adopt clause 5 and not take the very drastic step of removing it from the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats applaud the Government for adopting the concept of putting guidelines into legislative form. We believe that this means of prescribing the method by which tenders or submissions will be considered by the Government, whether it be a State or Federal Government or a State or Federal Minister, is a very desirable thing. We feel that, in endeavouring to achieve an objective, the Government has gone too far in scrubbing the tender system for a whole range of possible areas that could use tenders. In particular paragraphs (e) and (f) of clause 5 virtually leave it to the discretion of what I think can be accurately described as vested interests, because it would be in the interest of a State to ensure that there are no competitive tenders to be considered. The vested interest of a State, put to the Federal Minister on whatever basis, whether it is a friendly party relationship or any other kind of relationship, could result in the public at large, which is paying for this road funding system, suffering.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that it is desirable to have these guidelines somewhere, it is possible for these guidelines to be included in the system right at this moment. Under the existing legislation the Federal Minister has authority to lay down the guidelines. I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), who is representing the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris), specifically to see whether the guidelines that are inserted in clause 5 can be introduced in new legislation not to exempt tendering but to provide the guidelines for a State Government making a recommendation to the Federal Minister for the acceptance of statutory bodies' submissions in preference to a tender which may be better than that submitted by a State or local government body. That is a specific request to which I would like the Minister to respond.

Generally, we support Senator Peter Rae's submission on behalf of the Opposition that there is no justification for throwing out the tender system. Even with the provisions that are included in clause 5 there is nothing to prevent a State government and a Federal Minister from taking into account all those provisions right at this moment. But the old legislation has the advantage of a State and, in particular, the Federal Government having alternative proposals from private contractor tenderers.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the cross-check that is important.

—It is. It is a cross-check not just for a State government or the Federal Minister but also for us to know that it has been done the right way. That is all that we are insisting on. As I said earlier, I hope that the Government will see its way clear to use these guidelines. So instead of it being a matter of consultation between the Federal Minister and the State governments to alter the procedural guidelines, they are prescribed by Federal legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a valid argument to be made for works to be put to tender. That argument has been made in representations from the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors. I take the same view as I did on the previous occasion, however. In fiscal relationships between the Commonwealth and the States, in areas which are currently under consideration, the Commonwealth should not use either its perceived constitutional powers or its fiscal powers to impose its will on the States or local government. The Senate will recall that I took that view in the Tasmanian dams case. I believe that this is another extension of the appropriate application of the principle of subsidiarity. Power in these matters should reside with the smallest group capable of efficiently performing the functions for which the power is required. This is an important area of responsibility of the States and local government. Of course, I recognise that the bicentennial road development program is a matter of co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States. Despite that fact, I consider that clause 5 of the Bill goes at least some of the way towards applying the principle I have enunciated. No doubt the Government has not inserted this clause for those high ideals; nevertheless, it has attracted my vote on that amendment on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Chairman and the Committee to bear with me as I take the opportunity to raise another matter. I did not speak but voted with the Opposition on the last occasion on which the matter of the fuel excise increase going to Consolidated Revenue rather than to the ABRD Trust Fund was discussed. I voted with the Opposition on that occasion because I believed a proportion of the increase ought to go to the Trust Fund. But is the Minister in a position to say what will happen with the levy in 1988 at the end of the ABRD program? What will happen then to the 2 per cent levy on the indexed excise? Will the amount of the levy be readjusted to compensate for the indexation of the excise?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is difficult to respond to Senator Harradine and indicate what will happen in 1988. I do not know whether any of us will still be here then. Clearly road construction will not end in 1988. That will be a peak period. We support the previous Government's decision to carry out an emphasised road program to culminate in 1988 as part of the bicentenary celebrations. Of course, what happens after that will be a matter for the government of the day to determine. I assume it will still be a Hawke Labor government. If so, we will maintain an emphasis on road construction until we have in Australia a road system which is comparable to the best systems in the world. But that is too far off for us to contemplate at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it perhaps is not appreciated that the acceptance of clause 5 would allow the operation of the decentralised decision-making processes which allegedly we all support. There are regions in Australia where it is impossible, for example, for the private contracting system to operate, where because of the isolation from the mainstream of urban and city life the local authorities are, as one honourable senator said yesterday, an integral part of the local community, of the local economy. Therefore, in this clause we have provided an opportunity for the States to make application to the Commonwealth for an exemption from the tendering requirement. In such areas the local construction authorities, which in many cases in the far flung areas of our Commonwealth, in particular in Queensland, are the only ones able to carry out the work.

It would be inappropriate to remove the discretion provided for in this clause. It is not a matter of the Federal Minister having a say; it is a matter of the States initiating an application on behalf of local construction authorities. It is true that probably in most cases it would be a public authority that would make a request through the State to the Commonwealth for the application of this provision. Of course, the Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) will expect the State authority to provide evidence to the effect that no other course is available to the State, that the local authority is the only body capable of undertaking the construction work and that the private construction industry is not able to contribute in the same way as the local authority is able to contribute.

From what Senator Bjelke-Petersen said yesterday about the great hinterland, many of the private construction authorities would not be interested in the work in many of those isolated communities. In those circumstances, in Queensland, for example, clause 5 is designed for the Queensland Minister to be able to make representations to the Commonwealth. Based on the evidence, the Minister for Transport will have an opportunity to make a decision. To remove clause 5 would be a retrograde step, one which I ask the Committee not to support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this amendment because it goes to the very heart of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Bill. If this Parliament is concerned about adopting a responsible position on the expenditure of public funds and about getting value for money and accountability, we have no choice but to support the amendment. I do not want to go into party philosophical differences, but it really gets down to that , to whether one is a socialist or whether one believes in the private enterprise system. If one is a socialist and thinks government can do it better, one votes for the Bill as it is. If one believes in private enterprise and knows from the experience of nearly two years operation of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act that we buy nearly 50 per cent more road mileage for the same amount of money by using private enterprise, if one believes that private individuals can do things more efficiently than can government bodies that are insensitive and do not have hungry shareholders pleading with them for performance, one votes for what the Opposition has done.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1984 for a Labor Minister to say that he believes in a decentralised form of government for Australia is just humbug. The Minister talked about the great hinterland of Australia and all that stuff. That is not true. Under the original Act the local authorities always could tender. They always had the opportunity to come in with bids. If no one else was going to come in because of the remoteness of the area the opportunity was there for local government and the obligation to do the work was on local government.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is all that is necessary.

—Absolutely. Local government has the inside running on the track. As I said in my speech at the second reading stage and as Senator Rae said in his speech, local government has concessions with respect to sales tax and other financial agreements on the huge cost of capital equipment, as well as local knowledge and the rest of it. If local government is competitive, as it is in so many shires in Tasmania, it will have its place. It will have its crack at the contract. But we have a responsibility to the taxpayers to see that we get value for the dollar we spend. Therefore, I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the comments of Senator Rae and Senator MacGibbon. The point the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) has made is not valid. In a remote area, if there is no private contractor there, it is a lay down misere for the local authority. The local authorities and the government departments are actually playing this game with a stacked deck to start with because of all things that have been mentioned: The tax concessions when buying equipment, the fact that they are on the spot, they have their gangs and housing there. So they are way in front anyhow. If we do away with the tendering system we will have no methods of checking on how funds are being spent. There will be no accountability. In actual fact, the tendering system does provide accountability. If the local authorities and the government department cannot compete successfully against the private operators with all that they have in their favour the tendering system is all more necessary because it does provide accountability.

SPEECH.PARA: Getting back to the point my colleagues made, the tendering system enables the best use to be made of the sparse taxpayers' funds. With this vast continent of ours and its small population-for 'small population' we can read small tax base- we have to make the best use of those funds. With all the best will in the world we will never have roads of the standard we desire, even were we to use the tendering system. But to make the best use of the funds that are available, there has to be accountability. Given the system under which we operate, that can be achieved only through a tendering system. I reiterate: That will not work against the State or local government authorities, although local government authorities have a head start anyhow. In remote areas where private operators do not want to go, the local authorities win with a lay down misere.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two further points come to mind. The first is what happens in 1988, which question was raised before. We can be certain of one thing-we will not have a Labor Administration in Australia in 1988. However, if this Bill prevails, a bureaucracy will be built up in every shire and in the main roads departments in every State. They will be fed off the milk cow of public funds from a Federal source until 1988. Then there will be thousands of people with no jobs to do, because the Bill we are dealing with is finite. In 1988, the year of the bicentenary, it finishes. If there is competition and if the bureaucracies that are built up within the shires and the State main roads departments are lean and efficient through the use of a tendering system, they will be able to face the future with certainty. We will need roads after 1988, but we must have the efficient administrative machinery which will bring that about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise firstly to repeat a question I asked of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), who is at the table. That is, will the Government consider introducing the guidelines I spoke of in legislative form in the future in the event of those guidelines being negated today as a result of the vote of this Senate? Secondly, I need to clarify the position of the Australian Democrats, having just heard Senator MacGibbon. I was disappointed to hear arguments which implied that all private enterprise is good and all public enterprise is bad, or vice versa. I think-I acknowledge that Senator MacGibbon implied this-there needs to be competition between the two sectors. It may well be that a public enterprise has the edge over private enterprise for a variety of reasons including the fact that it does not have to pay tax, or, in fact, make profits. But even given that that is so, I ask the Minister to recognise that the procedures laid down, which are based on recommendations by the respective State governments and which are approved by the Federal Minister, give the edge-not just a competitive edge-to public enterprise, should the State Government and the Federal Minister agree, to the government body. I read into Hansard one of the guidelines given under the approved procedures for inviting and dealing with tenders for national road construction works in Western Australia. Where the main roads department has lodged a bid the guideline states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may approve MRD undertaking the work or may direct alternative action.

That is written into the existing procedures. It is in the existing legislation. If the Minister had tenders in front of him, it would still be possible for him to ignore all of the tenders and give the work for whatever reason he may desire or consider appropriate-the reasons do not have to comply with the guidelines written into this Bill-to the main roads department. Following on from that, the second question I put to the Minister is whether he would accept that there may be a need to change those procedures so that not only the main roads departments but also State and local governments have the ability to benefit, under the guidelines laid down, once the tenders have been called and other factors have been taken into consideration. That is, that State or local government bodies can say, with the approval of the Federal Minister: 'In this case we want the work to be done by that local government body'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there seems to be an apprehension that somehow the Commonwealth, through the Federal Minister, will initiate changes to the tendering system or will suggest to the States some form of exemption that might be applied. There is absolutely no suggestion in the legislation or in the mind of the Federal Minister for Transport (Mr Peter Morris) that he will administer the legislation in such a way as to allow the States or the local authorities to build up their numbers and position at the expense of the private entrepreneur. That is not what is intended in clause 5. Clause 5 is a mechanism, not from the top but from the bottom, to ensure that where certain circumstances exist, States and local governments make the approach to the Commonwealth, and not the reverse. I have the assurance of the Minister that he does not intend to take any steps or any initiative in that area. Rather, he will act only in certain peculiar or particular circumstances where it is found that the existing Act, that is, the old Act-the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Act 1982-was, in its inflexible way, preventing the construction of roads, based on the best economic circumstances in a particular region.
—It is clearly understood that the initiative must come from the States.

—Senator Evans is proposing that tenders should still be called in all cases. Clause 5 allows an escape from that process, but only in extraordinary circumstances where there is no alternative. It is not envisaged that a contract would be let which would involve a cost to both the State and the local road authorities, which would, of course, increase the overall cost. As indicated in the second reading speech and in the second reading debate this legislation is about getting the best value for the dollar. But it does not follow that we cannot have a degree of flexibility, which is what clause 5 provides for. I assure Senator Evans that if it is found that in some State or region the legislation is being aborted by a neglect of the principles inherent in the Government's legislation, we would be prepared to amend the legislation to meet those requirements. Honourable senators should bear in mind that section 2 (2) of the Australian Bicentennial Road Development Trust Fund Amendment Act 1984, which has already been approved by the House of Representatives, states:

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments made by section 5 shall be deemed to have taken effect on 12 February 1984.

So to that degree it is already operating. I suggest that, having removed the inflexible position which previously existed, and created a flexible position based upon approaches made by the appropriate authorities in each of the States, that is, the Ministers for highways, and based upon the experience of the 1982 legislation and upon the consultation that we have had with the various State authorities, this legislation, which has flowed from that discussion, should proceed. If it is found that somehow or other the Government's view, the view of the Parliament, is being circumvented, we would be prepared to have a fresh look at amending the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question asked by Senator Jack Evans has not yet been answered. It is extremely important to me as a senator from Queensland, which contains so many country shires, that such a question be answered. Perhaps the Minister could respond to the specific question asked by Senator Evans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I answered that question. The Government does not propose that tenders should be called in all cases. There will be opportunities for States to make their case to the Minister. In those circumstances they will have to provide all of the relevant evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clause stand as printed.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being after 12 noon, by order of the Senate I will leave the chair and report to the Senate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ACCESS BY MINING COMPANIES TO ABORIGINAL LAND

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being after 12 noon, in accordance with Sessional Orders, I now call on Questions without Notice.

INTERJECT.PARA: ACCESS BY MINING COMPANIES TO ABORIGINAL LAND

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to his statement at the Australian Mining Industry Council meeting in Canberra yesterday, Wednesday, 2 May, in which he is reported to have supported calls for greater access by mining companies to Aboriginal land. I ask the Minister, firstly, in the event of the review of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act being conducted by Mr Justice Toohey being unsuccessful in easing the exploration log jam in the Territory, what actions does the Government intend to undertake to overcome the problem? Secondly, in light of the fact that various exploration companies-namely, Peko Exploration, Mobil Energy Minerals, Union Oil Development Corporation, Mistral Mines NL and Marathon Petroleum Australia Ltd-have dropped out of mining exploration in the Territory, will the Government take urgent action to review the problems, either by executive action or by parliamentary inquiry? I refer the Minister also to statements made at that same meeting yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, that in providing a just and reasonable framework to enable mining to take place on Aboriginal land on terms which pay proper--
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to ask his question. Questions are becoming far too long.
—Senator Chaney was referring to the Holding-Aboriginal Affairs resolution. My final question is: How does the Minister see this aspect of the problem? Will he support Senator Chaney's amendments?

—When addressing the AMIC seminar yesterday I expressed some concern at the very considerable delay in dealing with applications to prospect and mine on Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory. I do not have a copy of the speech with me but I did go on to say that if the present inquiry established by Mr Holding, which is under Justice Toohey, cannot produce satisfactory results then in my view the Government will have to have another look at the problem. That remains my position. I do not think I could-or even that I should-forecast at this stage precisely what action the Government would take should that happen.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, relates to publicity about in-line amusement machines being used for illegal gambling in Queensland. Does this illegal but apparently officially condoned gambling involve a cash business with a turnover of several million dollars a year? Has the Australian Taxation Office investigated whether tax is being avoided by the promoters of these machines? If not, will the Taxation Office undertake the necessary investigations to determine whether taxation is being avoided by those associated with the machines?

—I have a note from the Treasurer about this matter in which I am told that he is unable-and therefore I am unable-to confirm whether there is an illegal, but officially condoned, gambling industry in Queensland, as Senator Colston suggests or believes. The Commissioner for Taxation has advised that he is unaware of any particular gambling activities involving amusement machines in Queensland, which may also be associated with tax avoidance. As a general rule, the Commissioner seeks to ensure that tax legally payable in relation to any activity is paid. If the honourable senator has any detailed information regarding allegations that tax is being evaded or avoided, the Commissioner will , of course, be pleased to receive such information. I add that I will be very happy to pass on to the Treasurer a request that he sees that the matter is investigated promptly, particularly if Senator Colston can supply some more specific information such as particular locations and activities.

—I address a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. I have had many approaches from schools, particularly government schools, expressing great concern at the dramatic downgrading of government support for the operation of school cadet corps. The value of their operations in many areas, not the least of which is discipline, is highly regarded in the community. I ask the Minister whether the Government will urgently reconsider the virtual abandonment of this important facet of school life and support the cadet units at least to their former level.
—I will draw Senator Scott's question to the attention of the Minister and ensure that the honourable senator gets an early reply.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, concerns the measures recently announced by the Government to provide incentives to employers to boost apprenticeship intakes. I ask the Minister: What sort of a response has there been to the scheme so far, especially from employers in my home State of South Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The announcement made by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations of policies designed to boost apprenticeship training and apprenticeship intakes was made on 1 March. It provided for a 4.3 per cent increase in the existing Commonwealth rebate for apprenticeship full-time training from 1 January 1984. The package also provided for a number of cash incentives to employers to encourage them to increase the levels of apprenticeship training. That package was to operate between 30 June year on year. Employers have until 30 June 1984 to take action to avail themselves of that package. At this stage it is not possible to give any sort of objective understanding of the success of the package because the time of notification of desiring to be in the scheme does not end until 30 June this year.

ANSWER.PARA: Figures on apprenticeship training are compiled by State apprenticeship commissions and one is not able to provide an across Australia picture of those figures at this stage. But it is believed by the commissions that the proposals announced by the Minister on 1 March have been well understood and accepted in the community, and there has been a good response to them, but not one which can be reflected in statistics at the moment. Insofar as South Australia is concerned, the State training authority has indicated that it believes the measures are having success in boosting apprenticeship intakes in South Australia and that there are already signs of improvement after what was really a disastrous year in 1983.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Does the Minister agree that the changes to the health insurance arrangements through Medicare do not save pensioners who are already receiving free health care any expense, in other words, that they do not advantage pensioners in any way? Does she also agree that the drop in the consumer price index that is occasioned by the switch to Medicare does not represent a real reduction in the cost of living and that pensioners in particular will be affected by actual price rises during the March quarter? As the next pension adjustment in November will reflect the artificial drop in the CPI represented by the Medicare change, what action will the Government take to stop pensioners being disadvantaged by what has been described as the Medi- fiddle of the CPI?

—In response to the first part of Senator Chaney's question, obviously, if pensioners or anybody else are receiving free services, benefits cannot change that situation. If services are free they are free, and quite clearly no changes will affect that situation. So those who have free services will continue to do so. With regard to the impact on pensioners and beneficiaries of the fall in the CPI, I draw Senator Chaney's attention to a statement issued by the Acting Minister for Social Security, Dr Neal Blewett, who has reassured pensioners and beneficiaries that there is no cause for alarm as a result of the 0.4 per cent decrease in the CPI for the March quarter. The fall in the CPI has no impact at all on the May 1984 increase in pensions that has just taken place. Obviously there has been an increase and that increase is now flowing to beneficiaries. So the CPI decrease has no effect on that. There is a potential impact on the next pension increase in November, to which Senator Chaney's question drew attention. However, I can assure pensioners and beneficiaries and Senator Chaney that the Government is well aware of this potential impact and we are giving serious consideration to measures to cope with this in the Budget context.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to a proposal by the Queensland Premier to embark upon a loan raising venture in the Middle East? Is it a fact that the Queensland Premier is using an unknown middle man to raise these moneys, bypassing traditional services? Is it also a fact that the Premier will not disclose the financial arrangements he has with this latter day Khemlani? Does the Australian Government approve of such loan raising ventures by the States? What action can the Australian Government take to protect Queensland taxpayers' money from the latest outrageous scheme emanating from the Queensland Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Queensland Premier has appointed an agent to raise funds in the Middle East, along the lines suggested by Senator McIntosh. Indeed, that was confirmed, I think substantially, if not entirely, by the Premier himself on AM yesterday morning. I also understand that the purposes for which he intends to raise this money include, amongst other things, the building of a cancer clinic for Milan Brych, a hydrogen car factory for Stephen Hovarth, an oil mill for Dr Shrian Oskar and a round-the-world ticket for Wylie Fancher. The agent appointed is, I understand, Mr David Pan Meni, whom Senator McIntosh described as a latter day Khemlani and about whom little is known by me, but I assume that there is a prima facie case that he can be placed in the same sort of category as the odd characters who the Premier has collected around himself in the past, like Milan Brych, Shrian Oscar, Stephen Hovarth and Wylie Fancher.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to the last part of Senator McIntosh's question, any such movements of currency into the country by a State government or by private individuals would ultimately, of course, be subject to Commonwealth approval. I do not think the Commonwealth can entirely protect Queenslanders from the depredations of their Premier and the latest of his eccentric schemes, but I suspect that the latest eccentric scheme really will not come to anything, so the question of Commonwealth overview or control of foreign exchange movements will not arise.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ACCESS BY MINING COMPANIES TO ABORIGINAL LAND

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy a question concerning an article in today's Australian headed: 'Walsh backs Morgan on NT land rights'. Is it accurate that the Minister supported a call from Mr Morgan, Executive Director of Western Mining Corporation, for greater access by mining companies to Aboriginal land? I ask the Minister what is meant by the following quote from the article:

QUESTION.PARA: 'Senator Walsh said that if the current review of the Act being conducted by Mr Justice Toohey was unsuccessful in easing the 'log jam' in the Territory, then the Government would consider further action'.

Does that mean that the Government is considering reviewing the Aboriginal Land Rights Act with a view to taking away part of the land rights granted to Aboriginal people under the Act? Can we have a firm denial or affirmation of that? Finally, will the Minister condemn Mr Morgan's racial and religious bigotry--

TALK.START.PARA: —Religious bigotry?

—In his claim of Aboriginal cannibalism and infanticide as outlined in the article? For Senator Walters's benefit I will quote what Mr Morgan said yesterday. Did the Minister hear this? Mr Morgan said:

QUESTION.PARA: Nineteenth century accounts of clashes between Europeans and Aborigines, particularly in the north of Queensland, are quite explicit concerning the partiality of the Aborigines for the particular flavour of the Chinese, who were killed and eaten in large numbers.
Will the Minister denounce this example of naked racism?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I looked briefly at the Australian report to which Senator Chipp referred. He asked me whether I supported Mr Morgan. The answer to that is no, because at the time I spoke yesterday I did not even know that Mr Morgan had spoken, let alone what he had said. Indeed, I am not sure that he had even spoken at that stage.
—He spoke after you.
—It was after me, was it? I can assure Senator Chipp that there has been no collaboration between the two of us in any way. Regarding the general tone of Mr Morgan's comments, I think-
—I am not suggesting that there was. I am just asking you to denounce what he said.

—Yes, okay. I think his comments are highly exaggerated. Mr Morgan made a similar type of speech about another subject in London, I think at the beginning of this year or the end of last year, for which he was somewhat roundly criticised by my friend and colleague the Minister for Finance. I do not support the terms in which Mr Morgan put his case or his argument, but I am concerned and the Government is concerned-
—Do you denounce them?

—I denounce the terms in which he put his case, but the terms in which a case is put or exaggerated do not in my view necessarily invalidate the case itself. I and other members of the Government are concerned that, since 1981, 165 exploration licences have been offered to 42 companies on Aboriginal land and none has successfully negotiated a consent agreement. So 165 exploration prospects, not necessarily mining prospects, have been held up for almost three years because consent cannot be negotiated.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chipp asked me what 'further action' meant in my speech yesterday. I refer him to what I said earlier. I do not believe I can, and even if I could I do not believe I should, be specific about the sorts of things which the Government might do if Mr Justice Toohey's review and report cannot resolve the question. I think there is some reason to be concerned. There is a prima facie case, at least in my view, that in some instances difficulties are being incited by non-Aboriginal people. I do not say that as a general condemnation of people who are acting in a legal capacity for Aborigines, but I think there is a prima facie case that some white lawyers have recognised the income generating potential of delays and litigation. I do not think that has helped either the Aboriginal cause or the mining industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. While I do not ask him to specify the action the Government will take, can he see any way of rectifying the problem that he has enunciated, other than by amending the Aboriginal Land Rights Act?

—An amendment to the Act would work; I think that is beyond dispute. But I would prefer it if some other way could be found to overcome the problems, and I believe the Government would similarly prefer an alternative route, if there is one.

—My question, which is directed to the Attorney-General, refers to the Family Court. In view of the anti-social and violent behaviour associated with many family law settlements, does the Attorney see the need to review current Family Court procedures? Has consideration been given to recording and researching Family Court statistics, particularly disputed custody cases, and their possible connection with social and domestic violence, child abuse and mental health?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the extent that the honourable senator's question is prompted, as it may be, by recent violent attacks on the person and property of Family Court judges, I am simply able to say in general terms that a great many improved security measures have been put in place, the detail of which I do not propose to announce publicly for fairly obvious reasons. They have to do with the security of the courts themselves and the judges in the course of their travel to and from court and in their domestic environment.

ANSWER.PARA: To the extent that the question has a larger import about concern about the emotion and subsequent violence that is generated in family law matters generally, I think some specific things can be said. The procedures of the jurisdiction are continually under review by the Court itself, by the Family Law Council, which is one of the most successful advisory bodies with which I have had any dealings, and by officers of my own Department. The Family Law Council is due to report at the end of this year on the operation of the amendments to this Act which were put in place last year. Two amendments in particular last year were directed to the problem of domestic violence, section 114AA enabling a power of arrest to be attached to an injunction where a person has caused or is likely to cause bodily harm, and the companion section preserving the operation of State domestic violence legislation. We are hoping that the new remedial powers of the Court, together with the operation of the State legislation, will have an impact on this very distressing social problem.

It is the case that a good deal of further and continuing research is necessary to fully appreciate the nature of these problems and, accordingly, to devise appropriate solutions. In this respect, it is the case that the Court itself collects statistics on litigation and counselling. It is to have very shortly a computer facility installed which will obviously improve very markedly the ability to collect and evaluate such statistics. In addition, the Institute of Family Studies, based in Melbourne, whose annual report was tabled in this place yesterday, does research, with very elaborate statistical weaponry available to it, on a number of inter-related family issues affecting family and marital stability. In addition, I have recently written to all States requesting co- operation in the collection of statistics under the Family Law Act in relation to matters that arise in magistrates courts, which is another dimension again of this jurisdiction, and in one way or another I hope that we will have a much better co-ordinated approach to developing information and to understanding this extremely significant array of social problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I refer to the Government's assurances given by the Minister for Health in his Medicare legislation second reading speech that the one per cent Medicare levy deducted from pay packets would be shown separately on pay slips. Why has this undertaking been dishonoured by the Hawke Government? Is it that if the levy were shown separately on pay slips it could be regarded by the Statistician as a cost of health insurance and so would continue to be included on the consumer price index, while if the one per cent levy is shown as personal tax it has to be taken off the consumer price figures, so giving a very false picture of the increase in the cost of living?

—I presume that the last part of Senator Walters's question was meant to refer to the reduction in the CPI. I do not have information from the Minister for Health on the specific matter raised by Senator Walters. I will certainly seek an explanation for the current information to taxpayers and levy payers of the one per cent levy. I do not know whether the Department of Health could respond in any rational way to Senator Walters's rather bizarre speculation about why it has all happened. However, I will see what information there is about the ways in which the Government is informing the public of the one per cent levy.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: Can I have a decision by the Department on what I have put forward, a decision by the Department on whether that is a scenario?
—I will seek further information from the Minister for Health.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to links between recent increases in short term interest rates and the seasonal rundown in private sector liquidity due to taxation payments which are now occurring. Because these seasonal taxation factors tend to cloud the underlying trends or real movement in interest rates, will the Government investigate the feasibility of rescheduling or spreading taxation payments as a means of smoothing out liquidity flows, thereby reducing side effects on interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Maguire notes, because of the taxation arrangements there has been a seasonal factor for many years which tends to push interest rates higher than they would otherwise be at around this time of the year. For that reason the suggestion that Senator Maguire has made has some obvious merit. However, I would expect that there would be some difficulties, perhaps considerable difficulties, in actually applying the suggestion that he has made, but I will certainly put it to the Treasurer and see what the view of people who administer the taxation system is.

ANSWER.PARA: On the broader question of interest rates in general which Senator Maguire has raised it is, of course, quite clear that the trend in interest rates is downwards, even though for those seasonal reasons there have been small increases in some interest rates-not all interest rates-just recently. The trend is clearly downwards to the extent of between 1 1/2 per cent and 2 per cent in the last year.

Some politicians have made fools of themselves in the past by issuing iron-clad guarantees about what would happen to interest rates. The two people in particular whom I recall made fools of themselves in that area were the discredited former Prime Minister and discredited former Deputy Prime Minister in 1977.

It is safer and more responsible to talk about trends and what is likely to happen under certain conditions. The trend is already downwards. The negative consumer price index figure for the March quarter, which was released earlier this week, and the prospect or near certainty of another very low figure in the June quarter means that the next national wage case will contain a very small, perhaps even negligible, increase in wages.

So although the Medicare effect is a one-off issue in itself, with wage indexation it becomes translated into a new and significantly lower threshold of inflation. Obviously that will have some effect on interest rates. It may take some time for nominal interest rates to respond to lower inflation rates, but inflation has fallen very considerably. There is little if any doubt that it will continue to fall significantly again in the next nine to 12 months, and after a period nominal interest rates must follow the inflation rate downwards.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the view of the Minister for Resources and Energy of the recent agreement between China and the United States of America about the exchange of nuclear information and the supply by the United States of nuclear power equipment to China? Does the Minister see China as a future possible market for Australian uranium?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some information on this matter. I am advised that the agreement between the United States and China to which Senator Townley referred provides the legal framework regarding the ways in which guarantees and controls on nuclear related materials supplied by the United States to China may be applied. The agreement includes guarantees that no nuclear material or equipment subject to the agreement will be used for any nuclear explosive device or for research into explosive devices, that no material will be transferred beyond Chinese jurisdiction and that no material will be enriched, reprocessed or in other ways upgraded towards weapons material. China is in any case already a nuclear weapons state.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the final part of Senator Townley's question on whether Australia would consider supplying uranium to China, the issue has never arisen. I think it would be premature for me to forecast what the response of the Government would be should such a question arise. However, I can say that certainly uranium would not be supplied to China or indeed to any other country unless it were subject to the strictest and most effective safeguards which we believe can be applied.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which concerns the prosecution of an officer of the Department of Foreign Affairs, Mr Don Witheford, whose case was described by the Acting Chief Magistrate as being 'conceived in prejudice and born in bias', is directed to the Attorney-General. I ask: Is it a fact that a private Sydney barrister by the name of Hastings has been retained for the past several months at a cost of tens of thousands of dollars to assist Foreign Affairs officers working on Mr Witheford's prosecution? Is that barrister still working out of the Department of Foreign Affairs? If so, will the Attorney provide full details of Mr Hastings's hiring, including the costs involved and the level of security clearance, if any, he enjoys?

—I am not aware of the existence of any brief of this kind to anyone from the Sydney Bar, but I will certainly find out the information, either from the Minister for Foreign Affairs or from my Department, to the extent it may have been the case that if such a briefing did occur it was through my Department, although I do not believe it was. I will do my best also to get the other information for which the honourable senator asks.

—My question, which has serious implications for human rights in this country, is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. It relates to those Australians of Indo-Chinese origin who travelled to Canberra on 15 March 1984 for a peaceful demonstration against repressive acts of the Vietnamese authorities or government internally and in Kampuchea. Is it correct that these people were stopped by 15 to 20 carloads of police on the Hume Highway at Craigieburn on the northern perimeter of Melbourne? Is it correct that they were subjected to body searches, photographed and required to fill in forms which included questions about their level of education, prior military service and religion? Is it correct that the search extended even to children under nine years of age whose shoes and even nappies had to be removed? Were Australian Federal Police or officials in any way involved? If the police concerned were all Victorian police, were they acting on behalf of the Commonwealth Government, the Commonwealth police, or any department or agency of the Commonwealth Government?
—I do not have answers to the honourable senator's questions . I will seek them as soon as possible from the Special Minister of State.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Government continuing to give consular support to Father Brian Gore in relation to the trial being conducted in Bacolod city in the Philippines? Accepting Mr Hayden's assurance that the Australian Government has not involved itself in any consultations between the co-accused and the Philippines Government, nevertheless, can the Minister indicate the Australian Government's understanding of the stage reached in this trial which has proved so significant in determining Australian-Philippine relations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The latest brief I have on this, which is of today's date, is to the effect that following undertakings made by President Marcos during Mr Hayden's visit to the Philippines from 24 February to 26 February, measures were taken to expedite the trial of Father Gore and his co-accused in Bacolod city. The trial, which opened in Bacolod on 23 February, resumed on 1 March and sat on 17 days until 5 April. Between 1 March and 5 April the court adjourned seven times; each time, though, with the agreement of both the defence and the prosecution.

ANSWER.PARA: When the court adjourned on 5 April the prosecution was given until 10 April to present its exhibits and the defence until 16 April to submit any objections. It was also agreed that the prosecution would have a further 10 days in which to consider whether to recall any of its earlier witnesses, following which the judge would decide on any issues which had arisen. A defence petition for the dismissal of charges against all the defendants was lodged in Bacolod on 30 April. There have been discussions about the dismissal of charges between the defence and the Deputy Minister of Justice, Mr Borromeo. It is possible that the court will reconvene sometime in the next two weeks to respond to the defence petition, but it is not expected that the trial will resume until the second half of May. Officials from the Australian Embassy in Manila have attended all the court proceedings and will continue to do so when the trial resumes. A representative of the Law Council of Australia has also observed much of the trial.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I refer to the fact that Australia has lost 70 per cent of its Korean market share of meat exports to New Zealand, that Australia's share of the beef market in Japan has fallen from 64 per cent in 1979 to 50 per cent in 1983 and that Australia has recently lost an $18m Singapore beef tender. Taking into consideration that New Zealand, Australia's newest and most successful meat competitor, is being subsidised by its Government to the tune of $12m for inspection and grading of beef, would the Federal Government consider assisting the Australian meat industry by waiving the Commonwealth inspection levy which will cost the processors, and ultimately the beef producers, $40m annually?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been told by the Minister that he is aware of the response to the Korean tender and he shares the industry's disappointment that Australia did not gain a larger share. I think we all share that concern and disappointment. But there were several factors, I am advised, which operated in New Zealand's favour in respect of that particular tender. They included the fact that recent currency fluctuations favoured New Zealand and that increases in Australian domestic livestock prices had forced up Australian quotations. It follows inevitably, of course, that that would also have pushed up the income of Australian livestock producers. Viewed in that context, it is arguable, to say the least, and indeed I suggest that-
—Are you serious?
—Serious about what?
—Order! The Minister will answer Senator Boswell's question.
—About the recent increases in domestic beef prices?
—About the farmers being better off?

— Yes, better off than they were at some previous period and, I observe for the record, much better off than they were when the previous Government was in office; indeed, better off to the extent, in terms of net income, by about 100 per cent than they were when the previous Government was in office.

ANSWER.PARA: To the degree that Australia's uncompetitive tender in another country was attributable to increases in domestic prices there is an offset. I am advised that the tender was also for boneless beef only, a type which has traditionally been supplied by New Zealand. The Minister advises me that he is confident that once Korea resumes normal purchase patterns, Australia will maintain its position as a major supplier to that country. The last aspect of Senator Boswell 's question was whether the Government will forgo the meat inspection levy. I will put that to the Minister. But I expect that the response of the Government will be that the policy enunciated by the previous Government, that 50 per cent of inspection costs should be recovered from charges, will continue to be applied.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I refer to the newspaper reports of atomic tests at Maralinga, both those that have been publicised and those that it is claimed were conducted secretly. Are Australian servicemen who were employed to carry out those tests eligible for compensation by the Commonwealth?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Servicemen involved in the nuclear testing program at Maralinga in the 1950s and 1960s did not qualify for disability pensions. Peacetime service in the defence forces has attracted compensation under the Repatriation Act only since December 1972, when it was introduced by the Whitlam Government. However, servicemen are eligible for workers' compensation benefits. I understand that such benefits have been paid for illnesses and death claimed to have occurred as a result of the participation of servicemen exposed to radiation during those tests.

ANSWER.PARA: I draw the attention of Senator Hearn to the fact that on 15 December last-I think it might have been the last sitting day of the previous session-a Department of Health report entitled 'Health of Atomic Test Personnel' was tabled. Although some statistically significant associations were found between various tasks and subsequent illnesses, it was concluded that there was no association between proven radiation exposure and subsequent illness, and that there was no excess mortality which might have been due to exposure to radiation . I understand, of course, that those views have not been accepted by the Australian Nuclear Veterans Association which has been pressing governments in recent years to have further examination of the difficulties that they believe they experienced as a result of those tests. I point out, of course, as some of my ministerial colleagues in the Senate have said, that we are dealing with events that are now more than 30 years old. However, I can say that the Government is considering the need for a special compensation scheme, dealing with claims by veterans as well as civilians, arising from the British atomic tests in Australia. I am sure that that will also be taken up with the British Government, having regard to the joint co-operation that took place in those years.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: TASK FORCE ON SELF-GOVERNMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Territories and Local Government. I refer to the report that the Government has had since February this year from the Task Force on Self-Government. Does the Minister agree that the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory have a right to comment on the report's proposals before any government decision is taken? When will the report be made available for public consideration and debate? If the Government has already considered its position on the report's recommendations, when will that decision be announced?

—Senator Reid is correct in drawing attention to the fact that the Government is considering the development of self-government for the Australian Capital Territory. A task force has been working on this for some time, headed by its Chairman, Gordon Craig OBE. A draft report has been presented to the Minister. There is, of course, a great deal of detail to be dealt with in the report. The honourable senator will appreciate that I represent the Minister, therefore I am not necessarily completely up to date on the matter. I think the matter is still being considered by the Government. If the Minister has any further information on how much progress has been made by the Government in considering that report I will provide it to Senator Reid.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I refer to the nuclear waste produced as a result of the atomic tests and weapons trials conducted at Maralinga during the 1950s and 1960s. I refer also to the clean-up and burial operations and the return to Britain of part of the nuclear waste generated at Maralinga in 1979. I ask the Minister: Which government is responsible for the management of the nuclear waste from the British nuclear tests which remains at Maralinga?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted yesterday that the sycophancy of a previous, indeed a distant or almost ancient, Liberal-Country Party Government was the cause of the problem that has subsequently been inherited at Maralinga. That initial sycophancy and irresponsibility was compounded quite significantly in 1978 by a very recent Liberal-Country Party Government which accepted entire responsibility by Australia for the management of the waste that remained there. At that time a small quantity of plutonium embedded in salt was about to be returned to the United Kingdom. It was part of an agreement that that small quantity of plutonium would be returned to the United Kingdom and that Australia would accept entirely the responsibility for the rest of the contaminated material which was in the country. In quite explicit terms the United Kingdom had no further responsibility to have any other contaminated material repatriated to the United Kingdom.

ANSWER.PARA: A couple of days ago I considered the possibility of asking the Prime Minister whether he would consider writing to the British Prime Minister suggesting that the United Kingdom should accept responsibility, even to the point of repatriation to the United Kingdom, for some of this contaminated material. Whatever merit that may or may not have had, it is very difficult, to say the least, to pursue that course now given the agreement which the previous Government has made with the United Kingdom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry noticed that Mr Wally Curran of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union again took out on strike about 2,000 meat workers throughout Victoria? Does the Minister agree that the meat industry is already in deep trouble? Will not occurrences such as this lead only to more losses in permanent work, add even more to the costs and worsen the deplorable reputation of unreliability that Australia currently has at a time when customers world-wide are expecting more and more responsibility and service?

—I must confess I was not aware of the incident to which Senator Archer has referred, but I will seek the Minister's views on the likely effect of that. Since I am not aware of the incident itself I am, therefore, not aware of the background to it. But it would seem to me that at least some of the undesirable consequences to which Senator Archer has referred could-could-follow as a result of the action that he says has been taken. But I will seek whatever comment the Minister has to add to my comments and supply them to Senator Archer .

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS' AFFAIRS: NORTH QUEENSLAND

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. As the Minister is aware, I have received a number of representations from veteran constituents in north Queensland regarding difficulties they have experienced in gaining ready access to the services of his Department. Will the Minister inform the Senate of any progress towards the upgrading and expansion of the services provided by the Department of Veterans' Affairs in north Queensland?

—Following representations from north Queensland, from Senator Reynolds and the honourable member for Herbert, Mr Lindsay, I have examined the possibility of people living in the northern part of Queensland having more direct access to the Department's branch office in Brisbane. I have decided to upgrade the Townsville regional office, which acted as an agent for Brisbane. There is no doubt that client demands have grown very considerably in recent times and there is a need for an expanded operation. At the time when the requests were made to me by Senator Reynolds we had a staff of two operating from the Townsville office. They handled something like 450 inquiries a month. It was pretty clear that there needed to be some changes. By March next year the staff will be increased to about 15 and a wider range of services will be available, including medical examinations, treatment arrangements, service pension approvals and disability determinations-all of the matters that are dealt with by my Department. In those circumstances, there will be adequate staff capable of dealing with the increased number of demands that have been made upon my Department.

—My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. I ask: Is he or has he been concerned that the telephones in his Parliament House office or elsewhere may be or may have been bugged? If he is or has been, what basis has he for suspecting this? What action has he taken to establish whether his suspicions are correct?

—I do not believe I ought to say publicly what I have told my ministerial colleagues in a Cabinet situation. There were substantial grounds for the concern which I am reported to have expressed. I have done my best to check the matter out to the extent that the technical and other resources allow, but I do not feel it would be proper for me to comment further.

—I ask a supplementary question. I preface my question by saying to the Attorney-General that there is a public interest-and an interest on the part of all of us, I suppose, as we all deal with Ministers-in knowing whether Ministers are being subjected to this sort of surveillance. I ask the Minister: Does he suspect that, as has been reported, and is there any reason to believe that, indeed, other Ministers may have had similar treatment?
—Or other parliamentarians.
—Or other parliamentarians.
—I say only this: The next time the honourable senator rings me up he would be wise to moderate his language.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport whether he has seen the article in the Age of 30 April referring to the huge cost of road crashes, estimated at $3,000m a year. Is he aware of the figures by the Road Safety Council in that report that show fatal crashes are five times more costly than crashes with major injury and 265 times more costly than those causing only property damage? Can the Minister say whether the Government agrees with the claim in the report that Australians expect high standards for aviation and shipping safety but are very casual about road crashes? What action is the Government taking to change that attitude and to reduce the huge cost of road crashes?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my briefing notes the Minister for Transport has provided me with a copy of the booklet entitled The Cost of Road Crashes, which actually is an incredibly important book of statistics. It shows the cost to the community not only in human terms but also in monetary terms. For example, there is a table on page 7 which shows that the average cost was $300,000 for a fatality, $ 67,000 for a major injury, $8,000 for a minor injury and $1,900 for property damage only. The total community cost has been estimated as a result of the work by the Road Safety Council as follows: $1,000m for fatal crashes, $240m for those involving major injuries, $500m for those involving minor injuries, $970m for those involving property only-totalling $2,710m. This has prompted the Government to take a much higher national profile on road safety than has previously been the case. To that extent the Government will be launching a three-pronged campaign and will be publishing documents such as the documents I have before me which show the monetary cost of road crashes. There will be what has been described in my brief as slick television commercials, mainly aimed at the high-risk under-25 age group. The Government has already indicated during the debate on the road legislation today that there will be a dramatic increase in Federal spending on roads. In the 1983-84 period Federal spending on roads will be close to 50 per cent higher than that in the period 1982-83, which is an unprecedented increase.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government will also be commissioning relevant research that will be conducted at Sydney University into the effects of drugs, including pharmaceuticals, marihuana and alcohol taken in combination, on people's driving ability. I understand that this will be the first time such research has been conducted in the Western world. However, the Government indicates that it will not usurp the proper role of the States but that it will work closely with them on a number of joint ventures designed to overcome the obvious human costs as well as the monetary costs to the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is it a fact that there has been a reduction in Royal Australian Navy surveillance of the Bass Strait oil fields? What organisation, if any, has replaced the Australian Navy to ensure that security of these strategic oilfields is not placed in jeopardy and, in particular, their safety from ships travelling along Bass Strait? Can the Minister give an assurance that security measures have not in any way been reduced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am able to advise the Senate that the RAN Trackers were withdrawn from Bass Strait surveillance on 1 January this year as part of the planned phase-out of naval fixed wing aircraft. The RAN continues to provide a patrol boat on station around the oilfields for 24 hours a day, weather permitting. The limited presence of the RAN Trackers was not significant in the overall security measures adopted to protect these important oilfields. A more effective form of surveillance is provided on a 24-hour a day basis by the radar installed by Esso on one of the platforms. Esso is proceeding to install an additional radar which will improve the surveillance of Bass Strait.

ANSWER.PARA: Because of its relatively short time on task, the Tracker was of limited use, as I have said, in protecting the Bass Strait oilfields. Its surveillance coverage became primarily directed to the monitoring of shipping movements to prevent collisions between passing ships and the platforms. Even in this role the Tracker was responsible only for the initial detection in advance of the Esso radar of a small proportion of the intrusions in the restricted area around the platforms. The withdrawal of the Trackers has not reduced the effectiveness of the security measures protecting the Bass Strait oilfields. The Government believes that, with the introduction of the additional radar, the security of the platforms will be enhanced.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Resources and Energy to reports that the Federal Department of Resources and Energy is hampering investigations by a South Australian Health Commission inquiry, headed by Dr Ken Smith, into the effects on Aboriginal people of atomic tests at Maralinga. I also refer the Minister to his statement that the Government has no intention of hiding facts surrounding the atomic weapons tests in Australia. Will the Minister give an undertaking to make available to this Health Commission inquiry all information on the atomic tests at Maralinga without sanitisation by departmental officers? Further, will the Minister support the request by the South Australian Premier for the British Government to provide to the South Australian Government all records on the atomic tests at Maralinga?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen one report in the Adelaide Advertiser. Senator Bolkus referred to the undertakings which I had given not to suppress any of the facts relevant to this inquiry. At the time one qualification was given to that, or perhaps 1 1/2 qualifications, the first one being about material which was supplied by the United Kingdom on a confidential government to government basis. It seems to me that that confidentiality would have to be respected. Indeed, if it was not respected we would have no chance of obtaining further factual information from the United Kingdom. It is believed that factual information which may be held by the United Kingdom is relevant, at least to the common law claims for compensation which have been taken against the Commonwealth, and probably relevant to some other areas as well. So, without that qualfication, I cannot give the undertaking that Senator Bolkus requests to make everything available to the South Australian Health Commission, at least not without the prior clearance of the United Kingdom Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The report in the Advertiser, to which I have referred, quotes Dr Smith as saying that he was being refused access to Commonwealth material. I think that needs some qualification. Firstly, the background is that the South Australian Premier wrote to the Prime Minister on 8 March seeking access to this material. The Prime Minister replied to the Premier on 18 April. Shortly after that Dr Smith contacted the appropriate officer in the Department of Resources and Energy to whom he had been referred. He was told that his research assistant would have to obtain a security clearance before he was given access to the information and that some of it would require agreement by the United Kingdom for it to be released. I note that on 1 May Mr Bannon said in the South Australian Parliament:
I must stress that the attitude of the Commonwealth Government is most welcome because they are committed to open access to as much information as possible.

Mr Bannon did ring me, I think on that same day, stating that the South Australian officials had not been given ad lib access to the Commonwealth files. I think it is necessary, for the reasons I have given, that they not be given ad lib access to everything. But the South Australian officials were advised that specific requests for subject matter would be supplied in specific instances subject only to that restriction of the United Kingdom and maybe some Australian security material which would be classified as highly secret. I am advised that most of the material which Dr Smith is likely to require-this is the British material-would be confidential rather than secret. Therefore, it should not be difficult to obtain consent for access to the United Kingdom classification. Finally, I am seeing Mr Bannon this afternoon along with some officers from the South Australian Government-I am not sure which ones-and some officers from the Department of Resources and Energy in the hope that we can satisfactorily resolve this matter.
