TALK.START.PARA: —Following a cable from the Australian Associated Press last night an article appeared in this morning's Australian under the heading ' ''Deal'' delays pornography debate', in which I claim to have been misrepresented. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australian Democrat senators and the Government had 'done a deal to further delay debate on the importation of pornography', the Senate was told.

Senator Brian Harradine (Ind, Tas) said Senator Colin Mason (Dem, Qld) had ' done a deal' with the Attorney-General, Senator Evans, to delay debate on referring regulations governing the importation of pornography to the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs.
Of course, that relates to Senator Harradine's motion yesterday. On page 1461 of the Hansard we see a statement by the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, which states:

Against that background-I realise that I have trespassed just a little perhaps on the tolerance of Standing Orders-and by agreement with the Opposition, which I understand, wants some further time, which it has not had given the lateness of the hour of Senator Harradine's notice of motion, I move:
That this debate be now adjourned.

The Deputy President did not permit that. Following that the debate was adjourned on the motion of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in this place, Senator Durack. I find it quite extraordinary that any statement or report should be made especially since I did not speak on that matter nor at any time discuss it with Senator Evans or any other government member. I did not enter the debate. I did not utter a word or take any action which might have prompted that statement. We have a situation in which in fact there was an agreement and, indeed, it was Senator Durack himself who moved the adjournment. The allegation published in today's Press, attributed to Senator Harradine, that I did a deal to delay that matter is obviously quite without foundation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation. I agree with Senator Mason. Of course I did not accuse him of doing a deal in respect of that. In fairness to the Australian Associated Press, I notice that it put out a correction of that part yesterday afternoon. A report on the matter appeared in the Australian but presumably it did not pick up AAP's correction. Unless Senator Mason is complaining about misrepresentation in his being referred to as a Democrat from Queensland, there is no basis for complaint . The Australian newspaper got it wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the other aspect of the Australian newspaper's comment is that it did not follow the AAP story because it has me saying what in fact the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) said. What he said was in the AAP report that went to the Australian, but the Australian failed to put: 'The Attorney-General said . . . '. The remarks just follow on from what I was reported as saying. I think I have more reason to complain about the Australian article than Senator Mason has, particularly as it shows me as saying what Senator Evans said about this matter. I do not think either of us would agree with that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice , on 23 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Public Service Board recognise the qualifications of a Royal Australian Air Force senior technical officer; if not, why not.
(2) Does the Board recognise other skills gained in the defence forces and on what criteria does it base its judgment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I understand that there is no employment group in the RAAF called ' technical officer' or 'senior technical officer' but that the RAAF uses the terminology 'technician'. The Public Service Board recognises their qualifications for employment in the Australian Public Service (APS) in two ways :

(i) where a person's qualifications meet the Board's formal qualification prescription for draftsman and technical officer, that is, a Board approved technical and further education middle-level certificate or equivalent education qualification, the person is deemed to be qualified. Most RAAF technicians obtain such certificates as part of their RAAF training; and

(ii) following a review of RAAF training in 1977 by the Department of Defence, completion of RAAF basic radio/telecommunications training plus at least 800 hours formal training in one of several advanced RAAF courses is also accepted by the Board for APS draftsman and technical officer jobs.

(2) Yes, other skills are recognised under a variety of arrangements. The Public Service Board will write to the honourable senator providing details and an officer of the Public Service Board will be available to discuss the matter if the honourable senator wishes.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Canberra: Technical and Further Education Colleges

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 16 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: 1. Has there been a reduction in funds available for materials (foodstuffs) in respect of the initial catering and home science schools at the Canberra and Woden technical and further education colleges in the year 1983-84; if so, has there been a cancelling of certain courses for the first semester of 1983-84.
2. Will there also be a number of permanent teachers without a full teaching load because of such cancellations.
3. Will the cancellations bring about a reduction in fees greater than the savings effected in expenditure.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: 1. Canberra and Woden TAFE colleges each decided on the funds to be allocated to the home science area from the total amounts available to each for non-salary items. Each decided to allocate a reduced amount to the (non-trade) areas of home science where the cost of consumables is particularly high. Consequently a range of home science courses have been cancelled in the two colleges in the first semester of the 1984 academic year.

2. All teachers concerned at Woden TAFE college will have a full teaching load. At the Canberra TAFE college, a total of 14 teaching hours per week will be unused because of the cancellations of classes. Teachers with a slightly reduced teaching load will devote additional time to curriculum development and thus be fully employed.
3. The cancellation will not bring about a reduction in fees or revenue greater than the savings effected in expenditure.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 8 March 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs aware that the Tasmanian State Government is operating an accommodation allowance for tertiary education students amounting to $900 per annum (30 weeks at $30), while those students receiving tertiary education assistance scheme allowance either full or any part thereof receive only $500 per annum because of a regulation contained in the TEAS guidelines stipulating that even where a student may earn up to $2000 per annum, no more than $500 per annum must come from other allowances: If so, has the Minister any plans to correct this anomalous and inequitable situation which discriminates unduly against low income families who are struggling to send their children through tertiary education.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: TEAS is an income-tested scheme. It is not unreasonable therefore that in determining the level of TEAS entitlement regard should be had to other income available to a student, particularly when that income is in the form of an allowance provided by another agency broadly for the same purposes as TEAS. This along with other aspects of the income test is a matter which is kept under regular review. However it must be realised that to abolish the existing TEAS conditions governing income from other allowances or to raise the threshold would add to the costs of the scheme. This means therefore that the timing of any change must be determined in the context of the availability of funds and the priorities established for their expenditure.
